newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigeria refinery blames low output on crude supply.
newsitem.headline: Nigeria refinery blames low output on crude supply.

text.p: Nigeria's northern Kaduna oil refinery is running at 68 percent of capacity or 75,000 barrels per day as a result of an inadequate supply of crude oil, the managing director said.

"We are currently supplied 45,000 bpd of local crude from a capacity of 60,000 bpd and 30,000 bpd of imported crude compared with the 50,000 bpd required," managing director Morrison Tamuno told journalists in Kaduna on Monday.
Tamuno said the low allocation had forced the refinery to stop producing both aviation fuel and kerosene.
Kaduna processes both Nigeria's own light crude and heavier crude oil imported from the Middle East.

Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation spokesman Edoreh Agbah said in Kaduna that the state oil firm had asked the government for an increased allocation of crude oil to 320,000 bpd for refineries, but the allocation was cut to 250,000 bpd.
Nigeria's four refineries have a theoretical capacity of 445,000 barrels per day but produce well below that.
In the past two weeks much of Africa's largest oil producing nation has been forced to an economic snail's pace by fuel shortages.
On Monday the military rulers gave the go ahead for the first fuel imports since September.
